newsitem.title: UK: London gold, under pressure, tries to hold $350.
newsitem.headline: London gold, under pressure, tries to hold $350.

text.p: Gold struggled back above the psychological $350 an ounce level on Monday afternoon, after speculative selling had forced repeated downside tests.
"There has been good speculative selling today, which was probably in anticipation of the fund selling we've seen in the market recently," a dealer said.
"So far gold hasn't been run down too far, but it's looking shaky."
Bullion hit a low bid of $348.55 before rebounding to fix at $350.20 an ounce compared to $350.65 in the morning. It had closed considerably firmer on Friday, at $352.40/$352.90.
The market was nervously focusing on Tuesday's over-the-counter options expiry and a possible U.S. interest rate hike by the Federal Open Market Committee, dealers said.
"Dealers are trying to position themselves ahead of the options expiry on Tuesday. It's also the end of the first quarter ahead of a long Easter weekend, so it's all happening," a dealer said.
Bullion has been trading in a narrow band in recent days, and analysts said that $350 and $355 were the most popular "strike" prices for the March options expiry.
"The $350 level is very important in terms of the expiry and some people have a big stake in making sure it stays above here," a dealer said.
But also at the forefront of the market's consciousness was Tuesday's FOMC meeting, which many dealers saw likely to raise interest rates by 25 basis points.
"There is no doubt in my mind that a hike of 25 basis points has been priced into the market. The question is whether it's going to be 25 or 50 basis points," a dealer said.
Silver saw some selling as well, although the $5.09 support level held firm, and prices rebounded.
Silver was last indicated at $5.14/$5.16 since, compared to $5.17/$5.19 at Friday's London close.
Platinum and palladium started the European trading day on a weaker note, casualties of overnight selling. But prices remained generally static throughout the day.
Platinum was last at $375.50/$376.50, down $2.25, while palladium was just off the day's lows at $148.25/$149.25, down $3.75.
Both platinum group metals were still watching for fresh news on delayed Russian supply contract talks with Japan and planned strikes at the Russian Norilsk complex.
